DOC.HEAD: PDF Elements Escaped Because of Element of Surprise Incomplete
Eds: New throughout with report from briefing
DOC.TEXT: Failure of U.S. troops to achieve complete surprise in their attack in Panama resulted in the disappearance of substantial forces loyal to ousted leader Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., said today. Reporting on a three-hour briefing by Pentagon officials, Nunn and Sen. John Warner, R-Va., said substantial amount of cocaine and cash were seized in Noriega's personal headquarters in Panama City. Noriega faces drug-trafficking charges in the United States. Nunn and Warner, the chairman and ranking Republican member, respectively, of the Senate Armed Services Committee, noted that Noriega last year had been given the opportunity to leave Panama and go to a country from which he could not be extradited to the United States. ``He was given the opportunity to shove off and go to another nation and spend his dollars and not come back,'' Warner said. Warner said Noriega's refusal of the offer to leave the country was evidence of irrationality. ``His psychology, his neurotic tendencies were beginning to overcome him and destabilize him to the extent that ... he pushed those options aside, hunkered down and determined to cross that line which he had adhered to in the past, of not seeking Americans as targets of opportunity,'' Warner said. The diplomatic initiative came not just from the United States, but from other countries as well, Warner said. Because of that downturn and Noriega's increased ``irrationality'' and attacks against Americans, President Bush ``had every reason to believe violence was going to escalate if he did not act,'' Nunn said. He said an exhaustive search is continuing, but ``we did not have Noriega pegged down and he is still at large.'' Nunn said that while there was some surprise in the U.S. attacks that began at 1 a.m. Wednesday, it was not complete and that at least two companies of Panamanian troops are entirely unaccounted for. He said some troops and members of Noriega's paramilitary force known as the Dignity Battalions have dispersed into the countryside, where he said ``thuggery and violence'' are going on. He described the forces as ``armed and certainly very dangerous.'' Nunn said it is obvious that American military police will have to be used in Panama to stop looting and restore order. ``If that kind of chaos and looting goes on, I think Americans will be looked at by the Panamanian people with increased distaste,'' he said. Nunn said the administration intends to speed economic aid to Panama, adding that it is important ``that we get food in there very quickly.'' Army Lt. Gen. Tom Kelly, director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of staff, and other defense officials conducted the congressional briefing. Nunn said the briefing, which lasted more than three hours, reinforced his earlier view that Bush was fully justified in ordering the invasion. He cited Noriega's ``increasing irrationality'' and said more American lives might have been lost had Bush not acted. Nunn was critical, however, of the Reagan administration's indictment of Noriega on drug charges last year, saying he thought the move was ill-considered and had led to unnecessary trouble. ``Looking at lessons learned, when the Justice Department indicts someone, they ought to know what they are going to do next,'' Nunn said. ``I hope the Justice Department will learn a lesson out of this.''
